item.title: The Journey to Digital Filter Design: One-way and Two-way Filters
item.description: 1 One-way filtering For given filter transfer function $H(\omega)$, the filtered data $X_1(\omega)$ is $$ \begin{cases} X_1(\omega) &= H(\omega) \cdot X(\omega)\\ x_1(t) &= \mathscr{R} \{ \mathscr{F}^{-1}[X_1(\omega)] \} \end{cases} \tag{1}. $$ Eq. $(1)$ is called $one-way$ filtering, and it ensure that the onsets of original and filtered signals are at the same moment. 2 Two-way filtering However, if we want to ensure that the peaks of original and filtered signals are at the same moment, we need to filter again, which is named $two-way$ filtering.

item.title: The Journey to Digital Filter Design: High-pass Filter
item.description: 1 Basic princeples For a Butterworth high-pass filter, the squared frequency response is given by $$ |H(\omega)|^2 = \frac{1}{1+(\frac{tan\frac{\omega_c}{2}}{\frac{\omega}{2}})^{2N}} \tag{1}. $$ Using $tan\frac{\omega}{2}=\frac{1}{j}\frac{1-e^{-j\omega}}{1+e^{-j\omega}}$ and $z=e^{-j\omega}$, we have $$ |H(z)|^2=\frac{(-1)^N(\frac{1-z^{-1}}{1+z^{-1}})^{2N}}{(-1)^N(\frac{1-z^{-1}}{1+z^{-1}})^{2N}+tan^{2N}\frac{\omega_c}{2}} \tag{2}. $$ We know there $N$ repeated zeros $1$ of this transfer function, and the poles are little bit complicated. We first calculate $q_k=\frac{1-z_k^{-1}}{1+z^{-1}}$. $$ q_k= \begin{cases} &tan\frac{\omega_c}{2}e^{j\frac{2k+1}{2N}\pi}, \text{ for } N \text{ is even and }k=0, 1, 2, \cdots, 2N-1;\\

item.title: The Journey to Digital Filter Design: Low-pass Filter
item.description: Butterworth filters $$ |H(w)|^2=\frac{1}{1+( \frac{tan\frac{\omega}{2}} {tan\frac{\omega_c}{2}})^{2N}} \tag{1} $$ Low-pass filter Given the attenuation values $A_c$ and $A_r$ at cut-off frequencies $\omega_c$ and $\omega_r$, respectively, we first calculate the orders $N$ of filter. We know, $$ \begin{aligned} A_r &= -20lg|H(\omega_s)|\\ &= -20lg\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+(\frac{tan\frac{\omega _r}{2}}{\frac{\omega_c}{2}})^{2N}}} \end{aligned} \tag{2}, $$ and the orders $N$ is given by $$ N = \frac{1}{2}\frac{lg(10^{\frac{A_r}{10}}-1)}{lg(\frac{tan\frac{\omega_r}{2}}{tan\frac{\omega_c}{2}})} \tag{3}. $$ However, if you give the filter orders $N$, it can control the width of transition band of the filter.

item.title: Hilbert Transform
item.description: Firstly, compute the FFT of real signal $x(n)$ $$ X(k) = \mathscr{F}[x(n)]=\sum_{n=0}^{N-1}x(n)e^{-\frac{i2\pi kn}{N}} \tag{1}. $$ Let the FFT of $h(n)$ be $H(k)$ to yield $$ H(k)= \begin{cases} &X(k), &\text{ for } k=0 \\ &2X(k), &\text{ for } k=1, 2, \cdots, \frac{N}{2}-1 \\ &0, &\text{ for } k=\frac{N}{2}, \frac{N}{2}+1,\cdots, N-1 \end{cases} \tag{2}. $$ The hilbert transform $h(n)$ of the real signal $x(n)$ is given by $$ h(n) = \mathscr{I} \{ \mathscr{F}^{-1}[H(k)] \} \tag{3}.

item.title: Fourier Transform
item.description: 1 Introduction The $Fourier \ Transform$ convert the signal in one domain to another domain, for instance from time domain to frequency domain. The definition of $Fourier \ Transform$ is given by $$ X(\omega) = \int_{-\infty}^\infty x(t)e^{-i \omega t} \tag{1}. $$ For the operation in programming, we need its discrete form, namely, $$ X(k) = \sum_{n=0}^{N-1}x(n) e^{\frac{-i2\pi kn}{N}} \tag{2}, $$ where, $k$ is the index of the $k_{th}$ frequency point, and we can find the $k_{th}$ frequency like this $$ f_k = \frac{kf_s}{N} \tag{3}, $$ $f_s$ is sampling rate of signal and $f_s=\frac{1}{\Delta t}$.
